title: Blockchain Fundamentals
description: Learn the core concepts of blockchain technology
author: Web3 Education Team

sections.title: What is a Blockchain?
sections.html:
At its core, a blockchain is a distributed ledger that records transactions across many computers.

Each block contains a list of transactions, a timestamp, and a reference to the previous block, forming a chain of blocksâ€”hence the name 'blockchain.'

This structure makes the blockchain immutable, as changing any information would require altering all subsequent blocks, which is computationally infeasible.

sections.title: Blockchain Structure
sections.html:
A blockchain consists of connected blocks, each containing:

  • Block Header: Contains metadata like the timestamp, nonce (a number used in mining), and a reference to the previous block's hash.
  • Transaction Data: The actual information being stored, such as cryptocurrency transfers or smart contract interactions.
  • Hash: A cryptographic fingerprint that uniquely identifies the block's contents.

The hash of each block is calculated using the block's contents and the previous block's hash, creating an unbreakable chain. If any data in a block changes, its hash changes too, breaking the chain.

sections.title: Consensus Mechanisms
sections.html:
Blockchain networks use consensus mechanisms to agree on the state of the ledger without central authority.

The two most common consensus mechanisms are:

  • Proof of Work (PoW): Miners solve complex mathematical puzzles to validate transactions and create new blocks. Used by Bitcoin and (formerly) Ethereum.
  • Proof of Stake (PoS): Validators stake cryptocurrency to participate in block validation. More energy-efficient than PoW. Used by Ethereum 2.0, Cardano, and Solana.

Other consensus mechanisms include Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS), Proof of Authority (PoA), and Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT).

sections.title: Immutability and Security
sections.html:
Blockchain's immutability comes from:

  • Cryptographic Hashing: Each block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous block, creating a tamper-evident chain.
  • Distributed Nature: The blockchain is stored across many nodes in a network, making it difficult for an attacker to compromise the majority.
  • Consensus: Nodes must agree on the state of the blockchain, preventing malicious actors from altering records.

To successfully attack a blockchain, an attacker would need to control over 51% of the network's computing power (in PoW) or stake (in PoS), which is increasingly difficult as networks grow larger.

sections.title: Public vs. Private Blockchains
sections.html:
Blockchains can be categorized based on who can participate:

FeaturePublic BlockchainsPrivate Blockchains
AccessOpen to anyoneLimited to authorized participants
ExamplesBitcoin, EthereumHyperledger Fabric, R3 Corda
TransparencyFully transparentControlled transparency
ConsensusPermissionless (e.g., PoW, PoS)Permissioned (e.g., PBFT, PoA)
SecuritySecured by economic incentivesSecured by access controls
Use CasesCryptocurrencies, public applicationsEnterprise solutions, consortiums

Hybrid models also exist, combining features of both public and private blockchains.

quizQuestions.question: What makes blockchain technology tamper-resistant?
options: The linking of blocks through cryptographic hashes

quizQuestions.question: Which consensus mechanism is more energy-efficient?
options: Both use the same amount of energy

quizQuestions.question: What happens if data in a blockchain block is modified?
options: The block's hash changes, breaking the chain
The modification is approved by miners
The change is rejected and reverted
